title: EuroCIM 2026 Oxford, United Kindom
text:
The conference will be from 15-17 April 2026, with pre-conference courses on the 14th.

EuroCIM Oxford
15-17 April 2026






Mathematical Institute Andrew Wiles Building Woodstock Rd Oxford OX2 6GG
Get directions on Google maps












Thomas Richardson is a Professor in the Department of Statistics at the University of Washington, Seattle, USA.







Negar Kiyavash is a Full Professor and Chair of Business Analytics at EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland.







Philip Dawid is an Emeritus Professor of Statistics at the University of Cambridge, UK.








The invited speakers are organized into tandem thematic sessions. Each speaker will give their perspective on a similar theme.











Elizabeth Williamson is a Professor of Biostats and Health Data Science at London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, UK.







Johan Manuel de Aguas Pérez is a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Norwegian Centre for Knowledge-driven Machine Learning.

















Helene Rytgaard is an Associate Professor in the Section of Biostatistics at the University of Copenhagen, Denmark.







Pål Ryalen is a Researcher at Oslo University Hospital, Norway.

















Fredrik Sävje is an Associate Professor of Econometrics at Uppsala University, Sweden.







Corwin M Zigler is a Professor of Biostatistics at Brown University, USA.









The general theme of the meeting is “Causal Inference in Health, Economics, and Social Sciences”. Causal inference is broadly defined, and the focus is on statistical methodology and challenging applications that highlight necessary methodological extensions.

EuroCIM aims to provide a forum for people interested in causal inference to meet informally, for early career and established researchers to present and discuss the latest developments in the field, and to offer opportunities for networking to develop future research opportunities and collaborations.
EuroCIM evolved from what used to be the “UK Causal Inference Meetings” (UK-CIM). The EuroCIM steering committee consists of Alessandra Mattei, Rhian Daniel, Erin Gabriel, Fabrizia Mealli, Finbarr Leacy, Jon Michael Gran, Karla Diaz-Ordaz, Kate Tilling, Kjetil Roysland, Mats Stensrud, Niels Richard Hansen, Noemi Kreif, Oliver Dukes, Paul Clarke, Richard Emsley, Sara Geneletti, Sabine Landau, Michele Santacatterina, Stephen Burgess, and Vanessa Didelez.

Please note that registration for the meeting is not restricted to people from Europe, and we welcome participation from anyone who would like to attend!



Eurocim 2026 received support from:





Robin Evans, Ruth Keogh, Kyra Delray, Pablo Geraldo, Yasin Ibrahim, Linying Yang, and Jakob Zeitler

title: Invited courses
section: Introduction to Causal Inference, by Rhian Daniel (Cardiff University) and Erin Gabriel (University of Copenhagen)
text:
Introduction to Causal Inference, by Rhian Daniel (Cardiff University) and Erin Gabriel (University of Copenhagen)
Location: TBD Start time: 9:00 with a coffee break End time: 12:00
This course (which had its first incarnation at the UK-CIM 2016) is a whistlestop tour of the concepts and methods of causal inference, aimed at an audience of newcomers to the area, but who have a working knowledge of topics such as regression models. The emphasis is on giving enough background on the basic ideas so that the Euro-CIM meeting can be enjoyed without feeling lost. The material covered might therefore change slightly once the final programme for the meeting is known, but is likely to include:

the different languages of causality, e.g. do-notation, potential outcomes
how these languages express causal effects
the sorts of assumptions often relied upon to identify causal effects, and the meaning of identification
graphical models used in causal inference, including DAGs and SWIGs
regression models as causal models
methods based on the propensity score

The fact that the list above is far too long for a half-day course gives an impression of the nature of the workshop - rather than dwell on all the intricacies of the various methods and approaches, and how one might apply them in practice using computer packages, the focus will instead be on imparting the main ideas before moving swiftly on to the next topic.

title: Invited courses
section: Special Topics in Causal Inference, organized by Rhian Daniel (Cardiff University) and Erin Gabriel (University of Copenhagen)
text:
Special Topics in Causal Inference, organized by Rhian Daniel (Cardiff University) and Erin Gabriel (University of Copenhagen)
Location: TBD Start time: 13:00 with a coffee break End time: 16:00
This is a continuation of the Introduction course, where we will dive deeper into specialized tools and methods. The list below gives some examples, but may be changed or expanded to highlight some of the themes and topics that will be spoken about at the conference.

instrumental variable methods, including Mendelian randomisation
sustained exposures and time-varying confounders
target trial emulation
mediation analysis

title: Important dates
text: Abstract submission opens: 10 November 2025 Submission deadline: 16 January 2026 at midnight GMT 9 January 2026 Decisions sent: 16 February 2026

title: Important dates
text:
Personal information
You will be asked to provide an email address that will be used to communicate the selection outcome, the presenting author’s surname and first names, the presenting author’s affiliation, and the affiliations of any coauthors.

title: Important dates
text:
Abstract
The title of the submission must be no more than 250 characters. The abstract must be no more than 1250 characters.

title: Important dates
text:
Oral or poster presentation
There will be oral presentations, and poster presentations. In the form you can choose whether you would like to be considered for oral presentation only, poster presentation only, or either. In the latter case, if your abstract is not selected for an oral presentation, it will be considered for a poster.

title: Important dates
text:
Theme
There is a list of themes from which you can choose 1 or 2 that most closely align with your submission.

title: Important dates
text:
Review process
The review process will be blinded to the authors’ names, affiliations, and theme. After the deadline, responses will be sent to the email address provided.
